quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: There were many times where Google leadership reconsidered the acquisition and, "Should we sell YouTube?" if you can believe it or not.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A vivid reminder that even iconic products can look like failures early on, reinforcing the need for conviction and patience during unprofitable phases.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I remember in a board meeting, the new model really started to show legs and one of the board members, Brian Schreier at Sequoia, said it was the prettiest smile graph that he had ever seen.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A concrete example of a turnaround metric (“smile graph”) signaling a business model recovery from decline back to growth.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: You're thinking on a different time horizon. If you're a large organization and you do some performance management process twice a year and you're 0 to 1 incubator, you've already killed it. It's the wrong incentive.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A practical warning that standard big-company performance cycles can unintentionally suffocate 0→1 innovation, implying incubators need different incentives and cadence.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I get really focused on the thing that I'm working on and get really deep in the thing that I am working on and I have a hard time kind of multitasking a lot outside of that to be totally honest.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A candid explanation of why some high-performing PMs avoid public posting: deep work and focus trade off with “building in public.”

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I get to know people by doing work with them, by helping them. And it doesn't necessarily scale in the same way that Twitter does, but it's served me well so far and it's more kind of authentic and it's what comes more natural to me.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: An alternative networking model—relationship-building through collaboration and service rather than audience-building.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I think everyone can chart their own path and has a way that is sort of authentic to them and leans on their strengths.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A principle for career strategy: optimize for authenticity and strengths rather than copying others’ playbooks.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: What I often coach people is, do what you like. You're generally going to be a lot better at the things that really fill you up that really get you excited.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for choosing work: energy and intrinsic motivation are predictors of excellence.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: So why spend your time doing something that doesn't feel good because you think that it might lead to some success, where if you lean on what's authentic to you and what makes you happy, chances are you're going to be one of the best people at those things?
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive career heuristic: pursuing what feels right can be a competitive advantage, not a tradeoff.

quotes.topic_title: Why Noam avoids social media and posting
quotes.text: But just to be honest, it doesn't come authentically to me. It doesn't come naturally to me.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: Highlights an authenticity filter for deciding whether to invest in public posting as part of career strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Why Noam avoids social media and posting
quotes.text: I get really focused on the thing that I'm working on and get really deep in the thing that I am working on and I have a hard time kind of multitasking a lot outside of that to be totally honest.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: Frames deep work and limited multitasking as a deliberate tradeoff against maintaining an online presence.

quotes.topic_title: Why Noam avoids social media and posting
quotes.text: The way that I kind of get to know the industry and other teams or whatnot is just through working with people.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: Offers a relationship-building method based on direct collaboration rather than scalable social channels.

quotes.topic_title: Why Noam avoids social media and posting
quotes.text: I get to know people by doing work with them, by helping them. And it doesn't necessarily scale in the same way that Twitter does, but it's served me well so far and it's more kind of authentic and it's what comes more natural to me.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive career approach: prioritize high-trust, non-scalable collaboration over audience-building.

quotes.topic_title: Why Noam avoids social media and posting
quotes.text: So I think this is an awesome example of you can be incredibly successful as a product manager and as anyone in tech not investing time posting online.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Directly challenges the conventional wisdom that online visibility is required for career success in tech.

quotes.topic_title: Career advice: lean into what energizes you
quotes.text: I think everyone can chart their own path and has a way that is sort of authentic to them and leans on their strengths.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A simple career framework: choose an authentic path that leverages your strengths rather than copying others’ playbooks.

quotes.topic_title: Career advice: lean into what energizes you
quotes.text: What I often coach people is, do what you like.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: Direct, actionable advice for deciding where to invest your time and energy in your career.

quotes.topic_title: Career advice: lean into what energizes you
quotes.text: You're generally going to be a lot better at the things that really fill you up that really get you excited.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A performance heuristic: energy and excitement are leading indicators of where you’ll excel.

quotes.topic_title: Career advice: lean into what energizes you
quotes.text: So why spend your time doing something that doesn't feel good because you think that it might lead to some success, where if you lean on what's authentic to you and what makes you happy, chances are you're going to be one of the best people at those things?
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: Counterpressure to “do what you should”: optimize for authenticity and enjoyment as a path to excellence.

quotes.topic_title: Career advice: lean into what energizes you
quotes.text: I am going to incriminate myself here, but I feel like the advice I always share with people is the best people are not spending time tweeting and talking online and sharing on LinkedIn. They're just doing the work. They don't have time for that sort of thing.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Challenges the conventional wisdom that building an online brand is required for success in tech.

quotes.topic_title: YouTube: killing your own project early
quotes.text: And maybe the first lesson was actually to look around at what the rest of the team was doing and be really honest and open about the relative priority of the thing that you're working on even if it might lead to your project getting canceled.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A practical prioritization mindset: assess your work in the context of the broader roadmap, even when it threatens your own project.

quotes.topic_title: YouTube: killing your own project early
quotes.text: So one of the things that I remember doing really on is actually talking to the leadership team and being like, "I don't think we should be putting 50 engineers on this project. Looking at the rest of the roadmap and the rest of the priorities, excuse me, I think this team would likely be better served elsewhere."
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A concrete example of advocating resource reallocation ("50 engineers") based on opportunity cost across the roadmap.

quotes.topic_title: YouTube: killing your own project early
quotes.text: Even though that was likely negotiating my way out of a job in month three, I don't know, I kind of felt like that was the right thing for the team and for the business.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: Counterintuitive career advice: prioritize the business over personal attachment or job security to build trust and long-term outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: YouTube: killing your own project early
quotes.text: That in the right organizations, even in large organizations, advocate for what's best for the team, advocate for what's best for the organization even if that means that it puts you at a particular difficult moment.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A reusable principle for decision-making and stakeholder management: optimize for org outcomes even when it creates personal discomfort.

quotes.topic_title: YouTube: killing your own project early
quotes.text: If it is a healthy team that rewards those sorts of decisions and actions, good things will happen. If it's not, that's good to know too. That's good to know early.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A diagnostic heuristic: how leadership responds to principled prioritization reveals organizational health early.

quotes.topic_title: YouTube: asking to be layered for growth
quotes.text: Eventually, I went to Salar and said, "Hey, I think I should actually report to Hunter. I think this would work better if we kind of combined the organizations this way and then we divided and conquered this way."
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A concrete example of proactively changing reporting structure to improve execution and organizational clarity.

quotes.topic_title: YouTube: asking to be layered for growth
quotes.text: But in that moment I was just like, "This is how I will do better work. This is how I will get better support. I will be happier and more productive and it'll be better for the team."
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A simple decision test for career moves: optimize for support, productivity, and team outcomes over optics.

quotes.topic_title: YouTube: asking to be layered for growth
quotes.text: I think internalizing that and understanding that and then trying to align whatever is under your influence towards that overall goal is very helpful and made me feel like, "I'm pretty confident this is going to be okay because it will lead to better results for the organization given what we're trying to do."
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A prioritization mental model: align your scope to company strategy and judge decisions by organizational results.

quotes.topic_title: YouTube: asking to be layered for growth
quotes.text: And so as long as I'm trying to push decisions or actions that actually lead to better results, if it's a healthy culture and organization, I should be okay.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A practical heuristic for risk-taking in career decisions: outcomes-first behavior is rewarded in healthy cultures.

quotes.topic_title: YouTube: asking to be layered for growth
quotes.text: It gave me a nose for what great feels like and what a high functioning team feels like. It's hard to know that without experiencing that.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A reminder that calibrating for excellence often requires firsthand exposure, which then improves team selection and judgment.

quotes.topic_title: Principles for business-first prioritization
quotes.text: a big part of your job is to think about what is best for the business and work backwards from that.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A clear prioritization mental model: start from business outcomes, then derive product decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Principles for business-first prioritization
quotes.text: I think ideally, things that are best for the customer, there's high overlap with that with things that are best for the business, but not always, right?
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: Highlights the core tension PMs must navigate: customer value and business value often align, but conflicts are inevitable.

quotes.topic_title: Principles for business-first prioritization
quotes.text: At Thumbtack, we had principles about which sides of the marketplace we wanted to serve in which order and when we serve Thumbtack. So it was customers first, pros second, and then Thumbtack last.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A concrete, reusable prioritization framework for two-sided marketplaces that resolves tradeoffs by principle, not debate.

quotes.topic_title: Principles for business-first prioritization
quotes.text: Well, we always just felt that what the pros need from us is more customers. What the pros need from us is high quality customers.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A practical marketplace heuristic: serving supply often means investing in demand quality/volume first.

quotes.topic_title: Principles for business-first prioritization
quotes.text: And so doing things like raising prices because we think it's good for the business, even though it causes liquidity issues in the marketplace might be a little bit of a local maxima, locally optimizing rather than globally optimizing.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that short-term monetization can harm marketplace health, framing the tradeoff as local vs global optimization.

quotes.topic_title: When to quit vs persist on a project
quotes.text: what kills most projects most early companies is stamina.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A simple diagnostic for why projects fail: not strategy or talent, but the team’s ability to sustain effort through difficulty.

quotes.topic_title: When to quit vs persist on a project
quotes.text: it feels like we're running uphill and chewing glass, and you're kind of like, "That's right, we want to do that. That's good for us. Take our medicine."
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for embracing the inherent pain of hard problems as part of the job rather than a sign you should quit.

quotes.topic_title: When to quit vs persist on a project
quotes.text: But ultimately, I think that what starts to happen is you start to lose the stamina and you're just not bringing your best self to the situation.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A practical “quit vs persist” signal: when energy drops enough that the team can’t operate at its best in ambiguity.

quotes.topic_title: When to quit vs persist on a project
quotes.text: They require just an ungodly level of faith and stamina.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: Sets expectations for high-ambiguity work: persistence is a core requirement, not a nice-to-have.

quotes.topic_title: When to quit vs persist on a project
quotes.text: I think that happens usually like in the startup case, a lot of times before you run out money or these other things.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: Counterintuitive observation that teams often “fail” psychologically (run out of steam) before they fail financially.

quotes.topic_title: Thumbtack downturn: SEO dependence and negative growth
quotes.text: SEO is a sort of a live by the sword, die by the sword channel of growth. I think that one channel growth company is always a no-no.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A clear warning against over-reliance on a single acquisition channel, especially one as volatile as SEO.

quotes.topic_title: Thumbtack downturn: SEO dependence and negative growth
quotes.text: in the early days when I was there, Thumbtack was seeing triple digit growth. Then we had a couple SEO hits that got us down to double-digit growth. And then not too long after that, we were actually, for the first time in the company's history, seeing negative year-over-year growth
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A concrete example of how quickly a growth narrative can reverse when a primary channel gets disrupted.

quotes.topic_title: Thumbtack downturn: SEO dependence and negative growth
quotes.text: So it was a really a tough moment of how much do we kind of spend to reinforce the old model while we're sort of building the new model, kind of changing the engine while the plane is flying.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A memorable framing of the resource-allocation tradeoff between sustaining the current business and rebuilding for the future.

quotes.topic_title: Thumbtack downturn: SEO dependence and negative growth
quotes.text: growth masks all problems.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A succinct mental model for why fast growth can hide fundamental product/market and operational issues.

quotes.topic_title: Thumbtack downturn: SEO dependence and negative growth
quotes.text: I'm kind of naturally paranoid. And especially as I manage growth, I often look at things and ask myself like, "Okay, what do I do right now if it went negative? How would I prioritize things if it went negative?"
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: An actionable planning habit: pre-commit priorities and contingency plans for a negative-growth scenario.

quotes.topic_title: Thumbtack turnaround: diversify channels and rebuild marketplace loop
quotes.text: So I mean, first was turning on multiple channels of growth.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A clear turnaround lever: reduce dependency on a single acquisition source by activating multiple growth channels.

quotes.topic_title: Thumbtack turnaround: diversify channels and rebuild marketplace loop
quotes.text: Thumbtack is actually a marketplace that is actually made up of thousands of marketplaces, right? Like DJs in Philadelphia is one marketplace, DJs in Atlanta is another marketplace, contractors in Sonoma is another marketplace.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A useful mental model for marketplace operators: treat the product as a portfolio of micro-marketplaces with distinct dynamics.

quotes.topic_title: Thumbtack turnaround: diversify channels and rebuild marketplace loop
quotes.text: So the main thing we did is to rebuild that whole loop, change the monetization model, build a system where essentially pros could provide instant quotes.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A concrete playbook: fix marketplace growth by redesigning the core loop and aligning monetization with a lower-friction experience.

quotes.topic_title: Thumbtack turnaround: diversify channels and rebuild marketplace loop
quotes.text: Another learning there is any product you work on that involves bits and atoms is exponentially harder than products that just involve bits.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that “simple” UX changes become far harder when they touch real-world logistics and supply behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Thumbtack turnaround: diversify channels and rebuild marketplace loop
quotes.text: If somebody was to come into our space and disrupt us and start now to become the new Airbnb, what would they do?
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical disruption-prevention question teams can use to prioritize transformative product changes before decline starts.

quotes.topic_title: Leadership-team alignment during hard times
quotes.text: And then when something happens like growth goes negative, that group is very important. And that group's ability to tackle hard things together is very important. I think that one important lesson from that is, no one can be a bystander on product strategy.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: Highlights a leadership-team operating principle for downturns: strategy can’t be delegated to a single function when conditions worsen.

quotes.topic_title: Leadership-team alignment during hard times
quotes.text: The CFO, the head of people, everyone needs to have a seat at the table when it comes to product strategy, what the company's doing and what they're going to do to grow out of the situation that they're in.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to broaden product-strategy ownership across exec functions to improve recovery odds in hard times.

quotes.topic_title: Leadership-team alignment during hard times
quotes.text: Because otherwise, in those hard times it can kind of be like a, "What have you done for me lately?" sort of a dynamic.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: Names a common failure mode in downturns—short-term blame dynamics—that cross-functional strategy involvement can prevent.

quotes.topic_title: Leadership-team alignment during hard times
quotes.text: it's also incumbent for people in our roles and engineering roles to bring strategy to that discussion, to that group, in a way that it is possible for everyone to engage and everyone to internalize and understand what it means for their area and to even have obviously a say in because they're on the leadership team at the end of the day.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A practical methodology: make strategy legible so every exec can engage, internalize implications, and contribute meaningfully.

quotes.topic_title: Leadership-team alignment during hard times
quotes.text: They should feel like their fingerprint is also on the company strategy, and as soon as it starts to feel like that's their world, that's our world.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: Memorable alignment heuristic: shared ownership (“fingerprint”) prevents siloed thinking and strengthens exec-team cohesion.

quotes.topic_title: Facebook NPE: value beyond finding the next Instagram
quotes.text: But I think in terms of was it a success or not because it didn't build the next Instagram I think is a little bit of the wrong bar to set for things like that.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: Reframes how to evaluate internal incubators beyond breakout hits, which changes what teams optimize for.

quotes.topic_title: Facebook NPE: value beyond finding the next Instagram
quotes.text: To some extent, it's like, "Did the group win the lottery or not? And let's judge there. Let's judge their success."
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for why judging incubators solely on unicorn outcomes is misleading.

quotes.topic_title: Facebook NPE: value beyond finding the next Instagram
quotes.text: So as an example, one of them is, at Facebook scale, doing things that don't scale or doing things that start out small was just a muscle that was really hard to come by, right?
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete capability incubators can build: practicing “start small” behaviors that big orgs struggle with.

quotes.topic_title: Facebook NPE: value beyond finding the next Instagram
quotes.text: At places like Facebook and Google, it's like it's hard to run an experiment with a hundred people. It's not hard, it's impossible, right?
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A specific, counterintuitive constraint at scale that explains why separate structures are needed for early validation.

quotes.topic_title: Facebook NPE: value beyond finding the next Instagram
quotes.text: So creating an environment where those sorts of constraints were lifted and were different was very beneficial, I think, to the organization and started to shed a light on some of the things that were broken that make it hard to build 0 to 1 in those sorts of environments.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: design incubators to remove key constraints and use them to diagnose what blocks 0→1 in the core org.

quotes.topic_title: How to run a startup-within-a-startup effectively
quotes.text: So one is I would say think really hard about the incentive system. Smart, good people, even if they're not trying to, they end up kind of gaming things towards the incentive system.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: Highlights incentives as the primary lever in internal incubators and warns that even well-intentioned teams will optimize for what’s measured/rewarded.

quotes.topic_title: How to run a startup-within-a-startup effectively
quotes.text: So for instance, if you're a large organization and you do some performance management process like twice a year and that's how you're going to evaluate and incentivize people in your 0 to 1 incubator, you've already killed it. It's the wrong incentive, it's the wrong timeframe.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A concrete anti-pattern: standard corporate review cycles are incompatible with 0→1 experimentation and can doom the effort upfront.

quotes.topic_title: How to run a startup-within-a-startup effectively
quotes.text: Just do what is best for the problem you're trying to solve in this moment, knowing that you're likely going to throw away a lot of this code anyway.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A practical methodology for incubators: optimize for speed and learning over reuse/standardization because early code is disposable.

quotes.topic_title: How to run a startup-within-a-startup effectively
quotes.text: Nike has this incubation lab. It's a completely different operating model. They recruit a completely different type of person, very different incentive system.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: Specific example of a company treating incubation as a distinct system—operating model, talent profile, and incentives—rather than a normal team.

quotes.topic_title: How to run a startup-within-a-startup effectively
quotes.text: When you're starting a company, you're not thinking like, "In the next six months, I'm going to get a promo and I'm going to get a good rating and things are going to go well." You're thinking on a different, excuse me, time horizon, and you're thinking about an outsized impact or an outsized incentive.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: Frames the key mismatch internal incubators must solve: startup-like time horizons and upside vs. corporate promotion cycles.

quotes.topic_title: Grammarly overview: profitable, larger than people think
quotes.text: We don't talk about it often, but Grammarly is a much bigger company from a revenue perspective than I think people realize.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: Highlights the strategic value of under-communicating scale to avoid scrutiny and misconceptions while building.

quotes.topic_title: Grammarly overview: profitable, larger than people think
quotes.text: The company has been around for 15 years and was profitable from day one, and continues to be quite profitable.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A concrete data point showing long-term durability and the power of early profitability in a subscription business.

quotes.topic_title: Grammarly overview: profitable, larger than people think
quotes.text: And that is actually quite intentional because the company was trying not to be noticed for a long time, very intentionally.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive go-to-market posture: staying under the radar can be a deliberate strategy to compound growth.

quotes.topic_title: Grammarly overview: profitable, larger than people think
quotes.text: People would often write off the company that like, "How is that a business? How is that a feature? These products already have it."
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: Captures a common dismissal pattern teams can exploit—building a business around a “feature” incumbents are assumed to cover.

quotes.topic_title: Grammarly overview: profitable, larger than people think
quotes.text: And that was very convenient for Grammarly because they could kind of navigate between these giants in tech and grow a very phenomenal business on this use case that people had written off.
quotes.speaker: Noam Lovinsky
quotes.context: A practical competitive strategy: use incumbents’ blind spots and low attention to grow in the gaps between platforms.
